item.title: 07/29: $1.89 Meals & Olympic Thrills!
item.itunes:author: Otron Daily
item.itunes:subtitle: July 29, 2024
item.itunes:summary: - Today's Daily Email Digest covers deals, finances, tech, and the Olympics. - **Deals:** EveryPlate offers new subscribers their first box for $1.89 per meal and 15% off their next seven boxes. - **Finances:** PayPal is offering PayPal Credit based on user history, but users are encouraged to carefully review terms and conditions. - **Tech & AI:** Gemini's new ability to remember conversation history is generating excitement in the AI community. - **Olympics:** Simone Biles returns to the Olympics in the women's gymnastics team event, highlighting the importance of well-being, while the U.S. men's basketball team won the 4x100-meter freestyle relay gold medal.
item.description:
Welcome to Your Daily Email Digest for [current date]. Let's dive into what's buzzing in your inbox.
**First up, a great deal for meal planners:** EveryPlate is offering new subscribers their first box for just $1.89 per meal, plus 15% off their next seven boxes. This could be a fantastic opportunity if you're looking to try out a meal kit service without breaking the bank.
**In financial news:** PayPal is rolling out a new offer for PayPal Credit. The offer is based on your account history, but as always, it's crucial to review the terms and conditions carefully before accepting any credit offer.
**Now for a quick look at the world of tech and AI:** Reddit's r/Bard subreddit is buzzing about Gemini's new ability to remember conversation history. If you're a regular user of AI tools, this development could significantly improve your experience, especially if you're working on long-form projects.
**Finally, some important updates on the Olympics:** The New York Times reports that Simone Biles is back on the Olympic stage in the women's gymnastics team event. After stepping back from the Tokyo Games due to mental health challenges, Biles's return is a reminder of the importance of prioritizing well-being, even at the highest levels of competition. In other Olympic news, the U.S. men's basketball team clinched gold in the 4x100-meter freestyle relay.
Don't forget to check out the New York Times's coverage of the Paris Olympics for all the latest updates and insights.
To wrap up, consider taking advantage of the EveryPlate deal if you're looking for affordable meal solutions. Review your credit usage before accepting the PayPal Credit offer. Stay informed about the exciting developments in AI and remember that even in high-pressure environments, prioritizing well-being is crucial. And, enjoy the Olympics! That's all for today's digest.

item.title: 07/27: Olympics Kick-Off & Market Upswing
item.itunes:author: Otron Daily
item.itunes:subtitle: July 28, 2024
item.itunes:summary: Today's digest covers the Paris Olympics opening ceremony, market updates including the used car market and Tesla's Q2 results, Buildspace Demo Day highlights, and quick hits on various topics including real estate and product launches.
item.description: Welcome to Your Daily Email Digest for July 27th. Let's dive into the highlights. **Olympics Update:** The 2024 Paris Olympics officially kicked off last night with a boat parade on the Seine. Despite some challenges, including arson attacks on French rail lines, the ceremony went off without a hitch. The Athletic reports that the United States won its first gold in the men's 4x100-meter freestyle relay. **Market Watch:** The used car market shows signs of cautious optimism, though overall inventory is down slightly from June. New car sales are expected to rebound in July, with a 5% jump forecast from J.D. Power. Meanwhile, Tesla's net income slipped by 45% in Q2. **Buildspace Demo Day:** It's demo day for Buildspace's Season 5. Over 2,000 participants are showcasing projects ranging from robots to AI applications. The event begins today at 10 AM PT on YouTube. **Quick Hits:** * Xfinity Mobile has released a new billing cycle statement and announced a change to how data usage will be calculated. * Apartment List has curated a list of rental properties similar to 3450 North Lake Shore Drive and is notifying users of a new available unit at Sono East. * Redfin is highlighting a new listing for a Chicago home at $296K and a price decrease on a property at 634-42 West Cornelia. * Health-Ade Kombucha announced the launch of a new flavor at Publix. That wraps up today's digest. Remember to check out the Buildspace Demo Day, and stay tuned for more updates on the Olympics. Have a great weekend!

item.title: Biden's Covid Bombshell & The Migrant Crime Myth
item.itunes:author: Your Name
item.itunes:subtitle: President Biden tested positive for Covid while facing pressure to exit the 2024 race. We also debunk the myth of migrant-driven crime surges...
item.itunes:summary:
Welcome to "Your Email Podcast," your weekly dose of insightful news and snarky commentary, straight from your inbox! This week, we've got a real rollercoaster ride from The New York Times, featuring everything from immigration debates to presidential health scares. We discuss the myth of migrant crime, Biden's potential exit from the 2024 race, his positive Covid test, and introduce The Morning newsletter.
Related links: - https://buildspace.so/s5/week/1 - https://sage.buildspace.so/nws5/1 - https://example3.com - https://example4.com

item.title: Buildspace w3
item.itunes:author: Otron Email
item.itunes:subtitle: A summary of all week 3 newsletters sent for your participation in buildspace.
item.itunes:summary: This week's Buildspace update focuses on launching your projects. Farza reviews 20 launches in a lab session, emphasizing the importance of good launches. The W3 pack includes tutorials to help with your launch, and there's a strong emphasis on taking action and getting your project out there.

item.title: Vendor vs. Vision: The Battle for the AI-Powered Internet
item.itunes:author: Otron Email
item.itunes:subtitle: We're tackling vendor hype with SeattleDataGuy, dissecting the truth behind "best practices" in data design. Plus, Cerebral Valley dives deep into the world of AI agents with Anon, a company building the toolkit to let your AI loose on the internet.
item.itunes:summary: SeattleDataGuy discusses the influence of vendors on data practices and standards, encouraging critical thinking about design decisions. Cerebral Valley explores AI agents with Anon, a company building integrations for AI to interact with various websites, highlighting the potential future of AI-powered internet interactions.
item.description: SeattleDataGuy discusses the influence of vendors on data practices and standards, encouraging critical thinking about design decisions. Cerebral Valley explores AI agents with Anon, a company building integrations for AI to interact with various websites, highlighting the potential future of AI-powered internet interactions.
